revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{History of Algeria}} {{History of Niger}} {{History of Chad}} The '''Neolithic Subpluvial''', or the '''Holocene Wet Phase''', was an extended period (from about 7500–7000 BCE to about 3500–3000 BCE) of wet and rainy conditions in the [[climate]] history of northern Africa. It was both preceded and followed by much drier periods. The Neolithic Subpluvial was the most recent of a number of periods of "'''Wet Sahara'''" or "'''Green Sahara'''", during which the Sahara region was much moister and supported a richer [[Biota (ecology)|biota]] and human population than the present-day [[desert]]. == Date ranges == The [[Neolithic]] Subpluvial began during the [[7th millennium BC|7th millennium BCE]] and was strong for about 2,000 years; it waned over time and ended after the [[5.9 kiloyear event]] (3900 BCE). Then the drier conditions that prevailed prior to the Neolithic Subpluvial returned; [[desertification]] advanced, and the [[Sahara Desert]] formed (or re-formed). Arid conditions have continued through to the present day.Sources differ on specific date ranges, which necessarily varied over such a wide geographic expanse. One (Bard, Kathryn A. (1999), ed. ''Encyclopedia of the Archaeology of Ancient Egypt.'' London, Routledge, pg 863) gives "9000–5000 BP," or 7000–3000 BCE, for the duration of the subpluvial. Another (Wilkinson, Toby A. H. (1999), ''Early Dynastic Egypt.'' London, Routledge, pg 372) places the end of the subpluvial c. 3300 BCE. == Geography and hydrography == During the Neolithic Subpluvial, large areas of [[North Africa|North]], [[Central Africa|Central]], and [[East Africa]] had [[Hydrography|hydrographic]] profiles significantly different from later norms. Existing lakes had surfaces tens of meters higher than today, sometimes with alternative drainages: [[Lake Turkana]], in present-day [[Kenya]], drained into the [[Nile River]] basin.{{Cite journal|last=Bloszies|first=C.|last2=Forman|first2=S. L.|last3=Wright|first3=D. K.|date=2015-09-01|title=Water level history for Lake Turkana, Kenya in the past 15,000 years and a variable transition from the African Humid Period to Holocene aridity|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0921818115001265|journal=Global and Planetary Change|volume=132|pages=64–76|doi=10.1016/j.gloplacha.2015.06.006}} [[Lake Chad]] reached a maximum extent of some 400,000 square kilometers in surface area, larger than the modern [[Caspian Sea]], with a surface level about 30 meters (100 feet) higher than its twentieth-century average. Some shallower lakes and river systems existed in the subpluvial era that later disappeared entirely, and are detectable today only via [[radar]] and [[satellite imagery]]. The event is argued to have ended quickly in some places{{Cite journal|last=deMenocal|first=Peter|last2=Ortiz|first2=Joseph|last3=Guilderson|first3=Tom|last4=Adkins|first4=Jess|last5=Sarnthein|first5=Michael|last6=Baker|first6=Linda|last7=Yarusinsky|first7=Martha|date=2000-01-01|title=Abrupt onset and termination of the African Humid Period:: rapid climate responses to gradual insolation forcing|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277379199000815|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=19|issue=1–5|pages=347–361|doi=10.1016/S0277-3791(99)00081-5}} and more slowly in others.{{Cite journal|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0033589402923562|title=Late Quaternary Climate and Vegetation of the Sudanian Zone of Northeast Nigeria - ScienceDirect|language=en|access-date=2017-03-10|doi=10.1006/qres.2002.2356|volume=58|issue=1|journal=Quaternary Research|pages=73–83 | last1 = Salzmann | first1 = Ulrich|date=July 2002}}{{Cite journal|last=Lézine|first=Anne-Marie|last2=Hély|first2=Christelle|last3=Grenier|first3=Christophe|last4=Braconnot|first4=Pascale|last5=Krinner|first5=Gerhard|date=2011-10-01|title=Sahara and Sahel vulnerability to climate changes, lessons from Holocene hydrological data|url=http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277379111002101|journal=Quaternary Science Reviews|volume=30|issue=21–22|pages=3001–3012|doi=10.1016/j.quascirev.2011.07.006}} Local feedbacks between vegetation and the atmosphere may explain the variability in the records.{{Cite journal|last=Kutzbach|first=J.E.|year=1996|title=Potential role of vegetation feedback in the climate sensitivity of high-latitude regions : A case study at 6000 years B.P.|url=http://cat.inist.fr/?aModele=afficheN&cpsidt=2511027|journal=Global Biogeochemical Cycles|volume=10|issue=4|pages=|issn=0886-6236|via=}} However, the agents of initial devegetation are unknown since they seem to occur rapidly in some areas and slowly in others, out of phase with changing [[Apsidal precession|orbital precession]].{{Clarification needed|date=July 2018}} The introduction of domesticated animals correlates in many places to a rapid change from grassland to scrubland vegetation, and it is hypothesized that [[Neolithic]] humans may have potentially played a role in stripping vegetation from the landscape, which induced cascading effects to the ecosystem and climate.{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=David K.|date=26 January 2017|title=Humans as Agents in the Termination of the African Humid Period|journal=Frontiers in Earth Science|language=English|volume=5|pages=|doi=10.3389/feart.2017.00004|issn=2296-6463}} For thousands of years, the Sahara ecosystem supported rich and varied flora and fauna, as well as large populations of [[Pastoralism|pastoralists]]. Researchers in 2018 demonstrated through a climate-vegetation model that abundant biota persisted longer than expected in regions where ancient pastoral societies once flourished, concluding that pastoral environment management contributed to regional delays of up to 500 years in the advancement of the Sahara's desertification between 6000 and 7000 years ago.{{Cite journal|last=Brierley|first=Chris|last2=Manning|first2=Katie|last3=Maslin|first3=Mark|date=1 October 2018|title=Pastoralism may have delayed the end of the green Sahara|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-018-06321-y|journal=[[Nature Communications]]|volume=9|issue=1|pages=4018|doi=10.1038/s41467-018-06321-y|pmid=30275473|pmc=6167352|issn=2041-1723}} == Ecology == North Africa enjoyed a fertile climate during the subpluvial era; what is now the Sahara supported a [[savanna]] type of ecosystem, with [[elephant]], [[giraffe]], and other grassland and woodland animals now typical of the [[Sahel]] region south of the desert, along with some now extinct [[megafauna]] such as ''[[Sivatherium]]'' and ''[[Pelorovis]]''. Historian and Africanist [[Roland Oliver]] has described the scene as follows:
[In] the highlands of the central Sahara Desert beyond the [[Libyan Desert]],... in the great [[massif]]s of the [[Tibesti]] and the [[Hoggar]], the mountaintops, today bare rock, were covered at this period with forests of [[oak]] and [[walnut]], [[Tilia|lime]], [[alder]] and [[elm]]. The lower slopes, together with those of the supporting bastions — the [[Tassili]] and the [[Tadrart Acacus|Acacus]] to the north, [[Ennedi]] and [[Aïr Mountains|Air]] to the south — carried [[olive]], [[juniper]] and [[Aleppo pine]]. In the valleys, perennially flowing rivers teemed with fish and were bordered by seed-bearing grasslands.[[Roland Oliver|Oliver, Roland]] (1999), ''The African Experience: From Olduvai Gorge to the 21st Century'' (Series: History of Civilization), London: [[Weidenfeld & Nicolson|Phoenix Press]], revised edition, pg 39.
== Cultures == {{Main|Prehistoric North Africa}} Clement and fertile conditions during the Neolithic Subpluvial supported increased human settlement of the Nile Valley in [[Egypt]], as well as [[neolithic]] societies in [[Sudan]] and throughout the present-day Sahara. Cultures producing [[Saharan rock art|rock art]] (notably that at [[Tassili n'Ajjer]] in southeastern [[Algeria]]) flourished during this period. The practical consequences of these changes took the form of increased abundance of fish, waterfowl, freshwater mollusks, rodents, hippopotamus and crocodiles. The riches of this increased aquatic biomass were exploited by humans with rafts, boats, weirs, traps, harpoons, nets, hooks, lines and sinkers. This "riparian" (river) way of life supported much larger communities than could that of typical hunting bands.Oliver, pg 37. These changes, along with the local development of pottery (whereby liquids could be both stored and heated) resulted in a "culinary revolution" consisting of soup, fish stew and [[porridge]].{{cite journal | last1 = Sutton | first1 = John E.G. | year = 1974 | title = The Aquatic Civilization of Middle Africa | url = | journal = [[Journal of African History]] | volume = 15 | issue = 4| pages = 527–546 | doi=10.1017/s0021853700013864}} The last mentioned implies the cooking of gathered cereals. The classic account of the riparian lifestyle of this period comes from investigations in Sudan during World War II by British archeologist [[Anthony Arkell]].Arkell, A.J. (1949), ''Early Khartoum'', [[Oxford University Press]]. Arkell's report described a Late Stone Age settlement on a sandbank of the [[Blue Nile]] which was then about {{convert|12|ft}} higher than its present flood stage. The countryside was clearly savanna, not the present-day desert, as evidenced by the bones of the most common species found in the middens — antelope, which require large expanses of seed-bearing grasses. These people probably lived mainly on fish, however, and Arkell concluded, based on the totality of the evidence, that rainfall at the time was at least three times that of today. The physical characteristics derived from skeletal remains suggested that these people were related to modern [[Nilotic]] peoples, such as the [[Nuer people|Nuer]] and [[Dinka]]. Subsequent radiocarbon dating firmly established Arkell's site to between 7000 and 5000 BCE. Based on common patterns at his site and at French-excavated sites already reported from [[Chad]], [[Mali]] and [[Niger]] (e.g., bone harpoons and a characteristic "wavy line" pottery), Arkell inferred "a common fishing and hunting culture spread by negroid people right across Africa at about the latitude of [[Khartoum]] at a time when the climate was so different that it was not desert." The originators of the wavy line pottery are as yet unidentified. In the 1960s, the archeologist [[Gabriel Camps]] investigated the remains of a hunting and fishing community dating from about 6700 BCE in southern [[Algeria]]. These pottery-making people (the "wavy line" motif again) were black African rather than Mediterranean in origin and (according to Camps) evidenced definite signs of deliberate cultivation of grain crops as opposed to simply the gathering of wild grains.Camps, Gabriel (1974), ''Les civilisation prehistoriques de l'Afrique du Nord et du Sahara'', Paris, pp 22 and 225–226. The site is [[Amekni]] near [[Tamanrasset]]. Later studies at the site have shown the culture to be hunter-gatherers and not agriculturalists, as all the grains were morphologically wild, and the society was not sedentary. Human remains were found by archaeologists in 2000 at a site known as [[Gobero]] in the [[Ténéré|Ténéré Desert]] of northeastern [[Niger]].{{cite web | url = https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/08/080815101317.htm | title = Stone Age Graveyard Reveals Lifestyles Of A 'Green Sahara' | publisher = [[Science Daily]] | date = 15 August 2008 | accessdate = 15 August 2008 }}{{citation | title = Lost tribes of the green sahara | author = Gwin P. | publisher= [[National Geographic Magazine]] | date = September 2008 }} The Gobero finds represent a uniquely preserved record of human habitation and burials from what is now called the [[Kiffian culture|Kiffian]] (7700–6200 BCE) and the [[Tenerian culture|Tenerian]] (5200–2500 BCE) cultures.{{cite web |last1=Dell'Amore |first1=Christine |title=Ancient Cemetery Found; Brings "Green Sahara" to Life |url=https://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2008/08/080814-sereno-sahara-missions.html |website=National Geographic News |publisher=National Geographic News |accessdate=1 June 2018}} Dotted wavy line pottery and fishing cultures have also been located in the [[Lake Turkana]] region in poorly dated contexts.{{Cite journal|last=Wright|first=David K.|last2=Forman|first2=Steven L.|last3=Kiura|first3=Purity|last4=Bloszies|first4=Christopher|last5=Beyin|first5=Amanuel|date=2015-06-01|title=Lakeside View: Sociocultural Responses to Changing Water Levels of Lake Turkana, Kenya|journal=African Archaeological Review|language=en|volume=32|issue=2|pages=335–367|doi=10.1007/s10437-015-9185-8|issn=0263-0338}} By 3000 BCE, it does not appear that the [[Turkana Basin]] was populated with harpoon and dotted wavy line pottery users, but fishing remained an important part of peoples' diets into the late Holocene. ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Abbassia Pluvial]] * [[Ancient Libya]] * [[Germa]] * [[Mechta-Afalou]] * [[Mousterian Pluvial]] * [[North African climate cycles]] * [[Older Peron]] * [[Piora Oscillation]] * [[Pluvial]] * [[Rock art of the Djelfa region]] * [[Sahara pump theory]] * [[Sahel]] * [[Sahel drought]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == Further reading == * Burroughs, William J., ed. ''Climate: Into the 21st Century.'' Cambridge, Cambridge University Press, 2003 * Howell, Francis Clark, and François Bourlière. ''African Ecology and Human Evolution.'' London, Routledge, 2004 (reprint of the 1964 edition) *[[Eamonn Gearon]]. "The Sahara: A Cultural History." Signal Books, UK, 2011. Oxford University Press, USA. 2011. *Garcea, E.A.A. (ed.) 2013. ''[https://books.google.com/books/about/Gobero_The_No_Return_Frontier_Archaeolog.html?id=fUy8gejsmSIC&redir_esc=y Gobero: The No-Return Frontier. Archaeology and Landscape at the Saharo-Sahelian Borderland]''. Frankfurt, Africa Magna Verlag. == External links == * [http://www.mymultiplesclerosis.co.uk/orbit/gilf-kebir.html Orbit: Earth's Extraordinary Journey] [[Category:Climate]] [[Category:Climatology]] [[Category:Climate history]] [[Category:History of the Sahara]] [[Category:Prehistoric Africa]]

revision.text:
'''Paludiculture''' is wet agriculture and forestry on [[peatlands]]<ref>[http://paludiculture.uni-greifswald.de/en/index.php Paludiculture term]</ref>. Paludiculture combines the reduction of [[greenhouse gas]] emissions from drained [[peatlands]] through rewetting with continued land use and [[biomass]] production under wet conditions <ref>Wichtmann, W., Schröder, C. & Joosten, H. (eds.) (2016): Paludiculture - productive use of wet peatlands - Climate protection - biodiversity - regional economic benefits. 272 p. {{ISBN|978-3-510-65283-9}}</ref>.
==Impact of peatland drainage and rewetting== Peatlands store an enormous amount of carbon. Covering only 3 % of the land surface they store more than 450 GT of carbon which is more than the amount of carbon stored by forests (covering 30% of the land surface) <ref>Bridgham, S. D., Megonigal, J. P., Keller, J. K. et al.: [https://repository.si.edu/bitstream/handle/10088/18978/serc_Bridgham_Megonigal_Others_2006.pdf?sequence=1&isAllowed=y The Carbon Balance of North American Wetlands]. Wetlands 26, 4/2006, S. 889–916</ref>, <ref>Dixon, R. K., Solomon, A. M., Brown, S. et al.: [https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Allen_Solomon/publication/6001774_Carbon_Pools_and_Flux_of_Global_Forest_Ecosystems/links/0fcfd50630a296d932000000/Carbon-Pools-and-Flux-of-Global-Forest-Ecosystems.pdf Carbon Pools and Flux of Global Forest Ecosystems]. Science Vol. 263, 1994, 185-190</ref>. Drained peatlands cause numerous negative environmental impacts such as greenhouse gas and nutrient emissions, subsidence and [[Biodiversity loss|loss of biodiversity]]. Although only 0.3 % of all peatlands are drained, peatland drainage is responsible for 6 % of all human greenhouse gas emission <ref>FAO and Wetlands International, Hans Joosten, Marja-Liisa Tapio-Biström & Susanna Tol Hrsg.: Peatlands - guidance for climate change mitigation by conservation, rehabilitation and sustainable use. 2. Auflage, Rom 2012. {{ISBN|978-92-5-107302-5}} [http://www.fao.org/docrep/015/an762e/an762e.pdf FAO-Broschüre "Peatlands"] (PDF; 5,4 MB)</ref>. Peatland rewetting significantly reduces environmental impacts caused by drainage.
==Arguments for the preservation of peatlands, and cultivation of crops thereon== * Due to the drainage of soils in many areas (for agricultural purposes), the soil height has dropped significantly over the years, and water quality has lowered as well. By making these areas wetter again, these problems are corrected to a large extent. As such, they can avoid the need of installations against [[rising sea level]]s ([[levee]]s, pumps)<ref>[http://www.landschapnoordholland.nl/project/omhoog-met-het-veen Omhoog met het veen]</ref> * By making soils waterlogged, carbon is unable to bind to oxygen, and hence will not escape into the atmosphere as [[carbon dioxide]] (CO<sub>2</sub>)<ref>EOS magazine, January 2017, De voordelen van natte akkers</ref><ref>According to Leon Lamers, one hectare of drained marshland emits 20 to 25 tons of CO2 per year</ref> * The preservation of the remaining peatlands is important for [[biodiversity]]. * The growing of crops extracts [[phosphate]] from the land, which is important in wetlands; it also helps to extract other nutrients from water, making it suitable for [[post-water treatment]] purposes<ref>[http://www.wur.nl/en/Expertise-Services/Collaboration-and-partnerships/CALM/research-1/freshwater.ecosystems.htm This purpose was demonstrated in the Aquafarm project by Wageningen University]</ref>
==Examples of potential crops for cultivation on wet and rewetted peatlands== The [https://greifswaldmoor.de/dppp-109.html Database of Potential Paludiculture plants (DPPP)] lists more than 1,000 wetland plants <ref>Abel, S., Couwenberg, J., Dahms, T. & Joosten, H. (2013): The Database of Potential Paludiculture Plants (DPPP) and results for Western Pomerania. – Plant Div. Evol. 130: 219–228</ref>, but only a minor fraction is suitable for paludiculture. Examples for potential and tested paludicultures are provided in the table below.
Tab. Examples for potential and tested paludicultures (modified after <ref>Abel, S., Couwenberg, J., Dahms, T. & Joosten, H. (2013): The Database of Potential Paludiculture Plants (DPPP) and results for Western Pomerania. – Plant Div. Evol. 130: 219–228</ref>, <ref>FAO and Wetlands International, Hans Joosten, Marja-Liisa Tapio-Biström & Susanna Tol Hrsg.: Peatlands - guidance for climate change mitigation by conservation, rehabilitation and sustainable use. 2. Auflage, Rom 2012. {{ISBN|978-92-5-107302-5}} [http://www.fao.org/docrep/015/an762e/an762e.pdf FAO-Broschüre "Peatlands"] (PDF; 5,4 MB)</ref>).
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Species !! Region & sites !! Utilization |- | [[Alder]] (Alnus glutinosa) || Central Europe, fen, oligo-eutrotrophic || Timber, fuel |- | [[Cattails]] (Typha sp.) || Central Europe, North America, West Africa, fen, polytrophic || Construction material (e.g. insulation), solid fuel, fermentation, fibers |- | [[Common reed]] (Phragmites australis) || Europe, China, fen, polytrophic || Construction material (e.g. thatching), paper, solid fuel, fermentation |- | [[Illipe Nut]] (Shorea stenoptera) || Tropics || Cocoa butter substitute |- | [[Jelutung]] (Dyera sp.) || Tropics || Latex |- | [[Sago]] ([[Metroxylon sagu]]) || Tropics || Starch |- | [[Sphagnum]] sp. || Worldwide, bog, oligotrophic || Growing media, revitalization |- | [[Water buffaloes]] || Europe, Asia || Cheese (mozarella), meat, conservation grazing |}

revision.text:
{{other uses}} A '''perfect storm''' is an event in which a rare combination of circumstances drastically aggravates the event.<ref name="Rts20080101"/> The term is used by analogy to an unusually severe [[storm]] that results from a rare combination of [[Meteorology|meteorological phenomena]].
==Origin== The Oxford English Dictionary has published references going back to 1718 for "perfect storm", though the earliest citations use the phrase in the sense of "absolute" or "complete", or for emphasis, as in "a perfect stranger".
The phrase appears in [[William Makepeace Thackeray]]'s novel ''[[Vanity Fair (novel)|Vanity Fair]]'': {{cquote|I have heard a brother of the story-telling trade at Naples preaching to a pack of good-for-nothing honest, lazy fellows by the sea-shore, work himself up into such a rage and passion with some of the villains whose wicked deeds he was describing and inventing, that the audience could not resist it; and they and the poet together would burst out into a roar of oaths and execrations against the fictitious monster of the tale, so that the hat went round, and the bajocchi tumbled into it, in the midst of a perfect storm of sympathy.||author=William Makepeace Thackeray|source=Vanity Fair}}
The first use of the expression in the meteorological sense comes from the March 20, 1936, issue of the ''Port Arthur News'' in Texas: "The weather bureau describes the disturbance as "the perfect storm" of its type. Seven factors were involved in the chain of circumstances that led to "the flood". <ref>{{cite web|author=May 8th, 2008 |url=http://www.grammarphobia.com/blog/2008/05/the-imperfect-storm.html |title=The Grammarphobia Blog: The imperfect storm |publisher=Grammarphobia.com |date=2008-05-08 |accessdate=2013-10-29}}</ref>
In 1993, journalist and author [[Sebastian Junger]] planned to write a book about the [[1991 Perfect Storm|1991 Halloween Nor'easter]] storm. Technically, this storm was an [[extratropical cyclone]]. In the course of his research, he spoke with [[Robert Case|Bob Case]], who had been a deputy [[meteorologist]] in the Boston office of the [[National Weather Service]] at the time of the [[storm]]. Case described to Junger the confluence of three different weather-related phenomena that combined to create what Case referred to as the "perfect situation" to generate such a storm: * warm air from a low-pressure system coming from one direction * a flow of cool and dry air generated by a high-pressure from another direction * tropical moisture provided by [[Hurricane Grace (1991)|Hurricane Grace]]
From that, Junger keyed on Case's use of the word ''perfect'' and coined the phrase ''perfect storm'', choosing to use ''The Perfect Storm'' as the title of his book.
Junger published his book ''[[The Perfect Storm (book)|The Perfect Storm]]'' in 1997 and its success brought the phrase into popular culture. Its adoption was accelerated with the release of the [[The Perfect Storm (film)|2000 feature film adaptation]] of Junger's book. Since the release of the movie, the phrase has grown to mean any event where a situation is aggravated drastically by an exceptionally rare combination of circumstances.<ref name="Rts20080101"/>
Although the [[1991 Perfect Storm|1991 Halloween Nor'easter]] was a powerful storm by any measure, there have been other storms that have exceeded its strength. According to Case, the type of convergence of weather events to which he was referring, while unusual, is not exceptionally rare or unique, despite the way the phrase is commonly used.<ref>(2000, June 29). "[https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2000/06/000628101549.htm Meteorologists Say "Perfect Storm" "(Not So Perfect)", ''[[Science Daily]]''</ref><ref>West, James. (2000, July 6). "[https://www.usatoday.com/weather/movies/ps/psname.htm The naming of ("The Perfect Storm"), ''[[USA Today]]''</ref>
==Other uses== The term "perfect storm" is nearly synonymous with "worst-case scenario", although the latter carries more of a hypothetical connotation.
"Perfect storm" has also been used as a metaphor for a relationship such as in the popular hit songs "[[Dark Horse (Katy Perry song)|Dark Horse]]" by [[Katy Perry]], "[[Blank Space (Taylor Swift song)|Blank Space]]" by [[Taylor Swift]], "[[Perfect Storm (song)|Perfect Storm]]" by [[Brad Paisley]], "[[Invincible (Kelly Clarkson song)|Invincible]]" by [[Kelly Clarkson]], and "[[Should've Been Us]]" by [[Tori Kelly]].
From the beginning, the phrase was in heavy use during the [[financial crisis of 2007–2012]], even to the point of pundits anticipating "another perfect storm".<ref>"[http://www.moneymanagement.com.au/article/Prepare-for-another-perfect-storm/520467.aspx Prepare for another perfect storm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100727211443/http://www.moneymanagement.com.au/article/prepare-for-another-perfect-storm/520467.aspx |date=2010-07-27 }}"</ref>
The phrase was awarded the top prize by [[Lake Superior State University]] in their 2007 list of words that deserve to be banned for overuse.<ref name="Rts20080101">{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSN0160393320080101 |title=Wordsmiths, avoid these words. |publisher=Reuters |author=Andrew Stern |date=2008-01-01 |accessdate=2008-06-19}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Blizzard]] *[[Butterfly effect]] *[[Hypercane]] *[[Spring tide]] *[[Superstorm]] *[[Synergy]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{wiktionary|perfect storm}} *[http://www.ncdc.noaa.gov/oa/satellite/satelliteseye/cyclones/pfctstorm91/pfctstorm.html National Climate Data Center]
[[Category:Weather hazards]] [[Category:Storm]]

revision.text:
{{short description|A large mass of relatively warm water in the Pacific Ocean off the coast of North America}} {{outdated|date=October 2016}} [[File:The Blob NOAA April 2014.jpg|thumb|300px|The Blob is an anomalous body having [[sea surface temperature]] much above the normal, seen here in a graphic of April 2014 by the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration|NOAA]].]]
'''The Blob''' is a large mass of relatively warm water in the [[Pacific Ocean]] off the coast of North America. It was first detected in late 2013 and continued to spread throughout 2014 and 2015.<ref name="phys.org">{{cite web |url=http://phys.org/news/2015-04-wedge-seawater-blob-blamed-marine.html |title=Wedge of warm seawater known as 'the blob' blamed for marine havoc |author=Monte Morin |date=24 April 2015 |publisher=phys.org |accessdate=27 April 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://earthobservatory.nasa.gov/IOTD/view.php?id=87513 |title=The Demise of the Warm Blob |date=16 February 2016 |author=[[NASA Earth Observatory]] |publisher= |accessdate=29 June 2016 }}</ref>
[[Sea surface temperature]] indicated that The Blob persisted into 2016,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://alaskapacificblob.wordpress.com/2016/05/19/the-blob-lives-update-from-rick-thoman/|title=The Blob Lives: Update from Rick Thoman|date=19 May 2016|author=Thoman, Rick|publisher=Alaska Ocean Observing System|accessdate=21 May 2016}}</ref> but was thought to have dissipated later that year. By September 2016, "The Blob" resurfaced and made itself known to meteorologists.<ref>{{cite news |last=Belles |first=Johnathan |date=21 September 2016 |title=The Blob is Back: Anomalous Warmth Returns to the North Pacific Ocean|url=https://weather.com/news/climate/news/the-blob-pacific-ocean-temperatures |publisher=[[The Weather Channel]] |accessdate=30 April 2017}}</ref> This warm water mass is unusual in ocean conditions and is considered to have a role in the formation of the unusual [[weather]] conditions felt in the Pacific Coast of North America.<ref name="phys.org"/> The warm waters of the Blob are nutrient poor and have adversely affected marine life.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/04/10/world/asia/climate-related-death-of-coral-around-world-alarms-scientists.html|title=Climate-Related Death of Coral Around World Alarms Scientists|date=9 April 2016|author=Innis, Michelle|publisher=The New York Times|accessdate=15 April 2016}}</ref>
==Origin== The Blob was first detected in the autumn of 2013 and the early months of 2014 by [[Nicholas Bond (Climatologist)|Nicholas Bond]] of the [[Joint Institute for the Study of the Atmosphere and Ocean]] of the [[University of Washington]], and his colleagues, when a large circular body of sea-water did not cool as expected and remained much warmer than the average normal temperatures for that location and season.<ref name="CNN-22Apr15">{{cite web |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2015/04/22/us/pacific-ocean-blob/ |title=Blob of warm Pacific water threatens ecosystem, may intensify drought |author1=Almasy, Steve |author2=Hennen, Dave |author3=Gray, Jennifer |lastauthoramp=yes |date=22 April 2015 |publisher=CNN.com |accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
Bond, who is the State Climatologist for Washington, coined the term "The Blob", with the term first appearing in an article in the monthly newsletter of the [[Office of the Washington State Climatologist]] for June 2014.<ref name="OWSC-03Jun14">{{cite journal |last1=Bond |first1=Nicholas |last2= |first2= |title=The Blob: Warm Water off the Coast of the PNW and What it May Mean for Our Summer Weather - A message from the State Climatologist |journal=Monthly newsletter |publisher=Office of the Washington State Climatologist |date= 3 June 2014 |pages=2–4 |url=http://www.climate.washington.edu/newsletter/2014Jun.pdf |accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
==Description== [[File:276D5E8400000578-3033598-A blob of warm water 2 000 miles across is sitting in the Pacifi-a-96 1428666569391.jpg|thumb|right|300px| The three "blobs" of warm water can be seen off the North American coast, ranging from Alaska to Mexico, seen in this graphic dated 1 September 2014.]] Initially the Blob was reported as being {{convert|500|mi|km}} wide and {{convert|300|ft|m}} deep.<ref name="phys.org"/> It expanded and reached the size {{convert|1000|mi|km}} long, {{convert|1000|mi|km}} wide and {{convert|300|ft|m}} deep, in the month of June 2014 when the term "The Blob" was coined.<ref name="OWSC-03Jun14"/><ref name="ScienceDaily-9April14"/><ref name="NFSCNorthPacFoodChain"/> The Blob now hugs the coast of North America from Mexico to Alaska and beyond, over a stretch of {{convert|2000|mi|km}} and more, and has formed three distinct patches, the first, off the coast of Canada, Washington, Oregon, and California, a region known to oceanographers as the [[Coastal Upwelling Domain]]; the second off Alaska and in the Bering Sea; and the third and smallest, off Southern California and [[Mexico]].<ref name="CNN-22Apr15"/><ref name="Peterson_et_al_2014">{{cite book | title=Ocean Ecosystem Indicators of Salmon Marine Survival in the Northern California Current |author1=Peterson, William T. |author2=Morgan, Cheryl A. |author3=Peterson, Jay O. |author4=Fisher, Jennifer L. |author5=Burke, Brian J. |author6=Fresh, Kurt |lastauthoramp=yes | date=December 2014 |publisher=National Marine Fisheries Service (Fish Ecology Division, Northwest Fisheries Science Center) & Cooperative Institute for Marine Resource Studies, Hatfield Marine Science Center|location=Newport, Oregon |url=http://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/research/divisions/fe/estuarine/oeip/documents/Peterson_etal_2014.pdf |accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
In February 2014, the temperature of the Blob was around {{convert|2.5|C-change|F-change}} warmer than what was usual for the time of year.<ref name="ScienceDaily-9April14">{{cite web|title='Warm blob' in Pacific Ocean linked to weird weather across the US |url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/04/150409143041.htm |work=Science Daily| accessdate=30 April 2015 |date=9 April 2015 |author=Hickey, Hannah}}</ref><ref name="Bond2015"/>
A NOAA scientist noted in September 2014, based on ocean temperature records, that the North Pacific Ocean had not previously experienced temperatures so warm since climatologists began taking recordings.<ref name="NFSCNorthPacFoodChain"/> <!--Please add info about the disappearance of the blob-->
==Cause== The immediate cause of the phenomenon is the lower than normal rates of heat loss from the sea to the atmosphere, compounded with lower than usual water circulation resulting in a static upper layer of water. Both of these are attributed to a static high pressure region in the atmosphere, termed the [[Ridiculously Resilient Ridge]], which has existed since spring 2014.<ref>{{cite news|last1=Morin|first1=Monte|title=Wedge of warm seawater known as 'the blob' blamed for marine havoc|url=http://www.latimes.com/science/la-me-wetter-days-20150419-story.html|accessdate=17 October 2015|publisher=Los Angeles Times|date=19 April 2015}}</ref> The lack of air movement impacts the wind-forced currents and the wind-generated stirring of surface waters. These in turn have influenced the weather in the Pacific Northwest from the winter of 2013–2014 onwards and may have been associated with the unusually hot summer experienced in the continental Pacific Northwest in 2014.<ref name="Bond2015">{{cite journal |author1=Bond, Nicholas A. |author2=Cronin, Meghan F. |author3=Freeland, Howard |author4=Mantua, Nathan |year=2015 |title=Causes and Impacts of the 2014 Warm Anomaly in the NE Pacific |journal=Geophysical Research Letters |volume= |issue= |pages= |doi=10.1002/2015GL063306 }}</ref>
The reason for the phenomenon is unclear. Some experts consider that the wedge of warm water portends a cyclical change with the surface waters of the mid-latitude Pacific Ocean flipping from a cold phase to a warm phase in a cycle known as the [[Pacific decadal oscillation]] (PDO).<ref name="phys.org"/> This poorly-understood change happens at irregular intervals of years or decades. During a warm phase, the west Pacific becomes cooler and part of the eastern ocean warms; during the cool phase, these changes reverse.<ref name="Mantua1997">{{cite journal |last=Mantua |first=Nathan J. |last2=Hare |first2=Steven R. |last3=Zhang |first3=Yuan |last4=Wallace |first4=John M. |last5=Francis |first5=Robert C. |year=1997 |title=A Pacific interdecadal climate oscillation with impacts on salmon production |journal=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society |volume=78 |issue=6 |pages=1069–1079 |doi=10.1175/1520-0477(1997)078<1069:APICOW>2.0.CO;2 }}</ref> Scientists believe a cold phase started in the late 1990s and the arrival of the Blob may be the start of the next warm phase. The PDO phases may also be related to the likelihood of [[El Niño|El Nino]] events.<ref name="phys.org"/>
NASA climatologist William Patzert predicts that if the PDO is at work here, there will be widespread climatological consequences and southern California and the American South may be in for a period of high precipitation, with an increase in the rate of [[global warming]]. Another climatologist, Matt Newman of the [[University of Colorado]], does not think the Blob fits the pattern of a shift in the PDO. He believes the unusually warm water is due to the persistent area of high pressure stationary over the northeastern Pacific Ocean. Dan Cayan of the [[Scripps Institution of Oceanography]] is unsure about the ultimate cause of the phenomenon, but states "there's no doubt that this anomaly in sea surface temperature is very meaningful".<ref name="phys.org"/>
==Effects== ===Marine life=== Sea surface temperature anomalies are a physical indicator which adversely affect the [[zooplankton]] (mainly [[copepod]]s) in the Northeast Pacific and specifically in the Coastal Upwelling Domain. Warm waters are much less nutrient-rich than the cold upwelling waters which were the norm till recently off the Pacific Coast.<ref name="NFSC"/> This results in reduced [[phytoplankton]] productivity with knock on effects on the zooplankton which feed on it and the higher levels of the food chain.<ref name="Bond2015"/> The Northwest Fisheries Science Center, Seattle has predicted reduced catches of [[Coho salmon|coho]] and [[Chinook salmon]], a major contributing factor being the raised temperatures of seawater in the Blob.<ref name="NFSC">{{cite web |url=http://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/research/divisions/fe/estuarine/oeip/g-forecast.cfm |title=Forecast of Adult Returns for Coho salmon and Chinook Salmon (2014-2016) |publisher=Northwest Fisheries Science Center |accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref>
Salmon catches in 2015 have dropped as the fish migrated away having found low levels of zooplankton.<ref name="CNN-22Apr15"/> Thousands of sea lion pups are starving in California leading to forced beachings.<ref name="NatGeo-11Apr15">{{cite web |url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/2015/04/150411-Pacific-ocean-sea-lions-birds-climate-warming-drought/ |title=Warming Pacific Makes for Increasingly Weird Ocean Life |author=Welch, Craig |date=11 April 2015 |publisher=National Geographic.com |accessdate=28 April 2015}}</ref> Thousands of [[Cassin's auklet]]s in Oregon have starved due to lack of food.<ref name="NatGeo-11Apr15"/>
In addition, animals which favour warm waters and which have never been seen as far north as Alaska, have been spotted, examples being the warm water [[thresher shark]]s (''Alopias'' spp) and [[ocean sunfish]] (''Mola mola'').<ref name="NFSCNorthPacFoodChain">{{cite web|title=Unusual North Pacific warmth jostles marine food chain |author=Milstein, Michael |date=September 2014 |website=Northwest Fisheries Science Center |url=http://www.nwfsc.noaa.gov/news/features/food_chain/index.cfm |accessdate=30 April 2015}}</ref><ref name="NatGeo-11Apr15"/> In the spring of 2016, acres of [[Velella velella]] were reported in the waters south of the Copper River Delta.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://alaskapacificblob.wordpress.com/2016/05/20/field-report-sailors-by-the-wind-jellies-spotted-in-the-northern-portion-of-the-gulf-of-alaska-just-south-of-the-copper-river-delta/|title=Field Report: Sailors by the Wind Jellies Spotted In the northern portion of the Gulf of Alaska, Just South of the Copper River Delta|author=Janzen, Carol |date=20 May 2016|publisher=Alaska Ocean Observing System|accessdate= 21 May 2016}}</ref>
The discovery of a [[skipjack tuna]] (''Katsuwonus pelamis''), primarily a fish of warm tropical waters, off [[Copper River (Alaska)|Copper River]], in Alaska, {{convert|200|mi|km}} north of the previous geographic limit, and a dead sooty storm-petrel (''Oceanodroma tristrami''), a species native to Northern Asia and Hawaii, along with a few [[brown booby|brown boobies]] (''Sula leucogaster'') in the [[Farallon Islands]] of California, besides other such records, has led to worries amongst marine biologists that the [[food web]] across the Pacific is in danger of disruption.<ref name="NatGeo-11Apr15"/>
Biologists from The [[University of Queensland]] observed the first ever mass [[Coral bleaching|bleaching]] event for Hawaiian coral reefs in 2014, and attributed it to the blob.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.uq.edu.au/news/article/2015/09/rapidly-warming-ocean-threat-hawaiian-coral-reefs|title=Rapidly warming ocean a threat to Hawaiian coral reefs|year=2015|publisher=The University of Queensland}}</ref>
===Weather and seasons=== Research from the [[University of Washington]] found positive temperature anomalies in the NE Pacific Ocean (upper ~100 m, greater than 2.5 °C, with temperatures at the coast below normal) for the winter period of 2013–2014. Heat loss from the ocean during the winter time was suppressed. During spring and summer 2014 the warmer sea surface temperature anomalies reached coastal waters. The anomaly may have had a significant effect on the unusually warm summer of 2014, with record high temperatures over parts of land in the Pacific Northwest. Offshore sea surface temperatures (SSTs) in the NE Pacific for the month of February were the greatest at least since the 1980s, possibly as early as 1900. Additionally they found anomalous sea surface pressure SSP, with a peak magnitude approaching 10 hPa, a record high value for the years of 1949–2014.<ref name="Bond2015"/>
Canadian senior climatologist [[David Phillips (climatologist)|David Phillips]] noted in May 2015 about the coming winter season, "If that blob continues, if it stays warm ... and then you add to that El Nino, it may complement each other and then it may be the year winter is cancelled."<ref>{{cite web | url=http://edmontonjournal.com/news/local-news/will-this-become-the-year-winter-is-cancelled-alberta-forecasters-monitor-el-nino-pacific-blob| title=Will this become ‘the year winter is cancelled’?: Alberta forecasters monitor El Nino, Pacific ‘blob’| date= May 2015| author=Paul Parsons}}</ref>
==See also== *[[Cold blob (North Atlantic)]]
==References== {{reflist|30em}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2018}}

~{{fossilrange|147}} | image = Chilesaurus holotype cast.jpg | caption = Cast of ''[[Chilesaurus]]'' from the Toqui Formation | type = [[Geological formation]] | prilithology = [[Conglomerate (geology)|Conglomerate]], [[sandstone]], [[tuffite]], [[ignimbrite]] | otherlithology = | unitof = [[Coihaique Group]] | subunits = | underlies = [[Katterfeld Formation]] | overlies = [[Ibáñez Formation]] | thickness = {{Convert|300|-|320|m|ft|abbr=on}} | area = | map = | map_caption = | location = | coordinates = {{coord|46.6|S|72.4|W|display=inline,title}} | paleocoordinates = {{coord|44.8|S|32.4|W|display=inline}} | region = [[Aysén Region]] | country = {{flag|Chile}} | extent = | namedfor = | namedby = | year_ts = | location_ts = | coordinates_ts = | paleocoordinates_ts = | region_ts = | country_ts = | thickness_ts = }} The '''Toqui Formation''' is a [[geological formation]] in the [[Aysén Region]] of southern [[Chile]]. It has been dated to the [[Tithonian]] stage of the [[Late Jurassic]] by [[uranium–lead dating]] of [[zircon]]s, providing an age of 147 ± 0.1 Ma.{{Cite journal|last=Suárez|first=Manuel|last2=De La Cruz|first2=Rita|last3=Fanning|first3=Mark|last4=Novas|first4=Fernando|last5=Salgado|first5=Leonardo|date=2015-12-28|title=Tithonian age of dinosaur fossils in central Patagonian, Chile: U–Pb SHRIMP geochronology|url=http://link.springer.com/10.1007/s00531-015-1287-7|journal=International Journal of Earth Sciences|language=en|volume=105|issue=8|pages=2273–2284|doi=10.1007/s00531-015-1287-7|issn=1437-3254}} It consists of an sequence of clastic sedimentary sandstones and conglomerates, interbedded with volcanic tuffs and ignimbrite.{{Cite journal|last=Salgado|first=Leonardo|last2=Cruz|first2=Rita Dela|last3=Suárez|first3=Manuel|last4=Fernández|first4=Marta|last5=Gasparini|first5=Zulma|last6=Palma-Heldt|first6=Sylvia|last7=Fanning|first7=Mark|date=2008-06-12|title=First Late Jurassic dinosaur bones from Chile|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1671/0272-4634(2008)28[529:FLJDBF]2.0.CO;2|journal=Journal of Vertebrate Paleontology|language=en|volume=28|issue=2|pages=529–534|doi=10.1671/0272-4634(2008)28[529:fljdbf]2.0.co;2|issn=0272-4634}} The dinosaurs ''[[Chilesaurus]]'' and indeterminate [[diplodocid]]s are known from the formation.{{Cite journal|last=Novas|first=Fernando E.|last2=Salgado|first2=Leonardo|last3=Suárez|first3=Manuel|last4=Agnolín|first4=Federico L.|last5=Ezcurra|first5=Martín D.|last6=Chimento|first6=Nicolás R.|last7=de la Cruz|first7=Rita|last8=Isasi|first8=Marcelo P.|last9=Vargas|first9=Alexander O.|date=2015-04-27|title=An enigmatic plant-eating theropod from the Late Jurassic period of Chile|url=http://www.nature.com/articles/nature14307|journal=Nature|language=En|volume=522|issue=7556|pages=331–334|doi=10.1038/nature14307|issn=0028-0836}}{{Cite journal|last=Salgado|first=Leonardo|last2=Novas|first2=Fernando E.|last3=Suarez|first3=Manuel|last4=Cruz|first4=Rita De La|last5=Isasi|first5=Marcelo|last6=Rubilar-Rogers|first6=David|last7=Vargas|first7=Alexander|date=August 2015|title=Late Jurassic Sauropods in Chilean Patagonia|url=http://www.bioone.org/doi/10.5710/AMGH.07.05.2015.2883|journal=Ameghiniana|language=en-US|volume=52|issue=4|pages=418–429|doi=10.5710/amgh.07.05.2015.2883|issn=0002-7014}} The formation was deposited in a [[fluvial|fluvio]]-[[river delta|deltaic]] [[depositional environment|environment]].[http://fossilworks.org/bridge.pl?a=collectionSearch&collection_no=83734 Toqui Formation, Aysén] revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} {{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} '''Trevor William Pescott''' (born 1934) is an [[Australia]]n [[natural history|naturalist]], [[conservation movement|conservationist]] and [[writer]], based in [[Geelong, Victoria]]. He was born in [[Ballarat, Victoria|Ballarat]] and educated in Geelong, qualifying with a Diploma of [[Civil Engineering]] from the [[Gordon Institute of Technology]]. He was subsequently employed as a municipal engineer with the [[Shire of Corio]] until his retirement.<ref>Pescott, Trevor. (1978). ''Natural Victoria''. Rigby: Australia. {{ISBN|0-7270-0524-3}}</ref>
Pescott was instrumental in the reestablishment of the [[Geelong Field Naturalists Club]] in 1961, serving as its President for three years and editing its magazine, the ''Geelong Naturalist''. From 1960 he wrote a weekly column (''By Field and Lane'') in the ''[[Geelong Advertiser]]''. He has been a regional representative to the [[Royal Australasian Ornithologists Union]] and a foundation committee member of the Environment Studies Association of Victoria. In 1973 he was involved in the formation of the Geelong Environment Council. In 1982 [[Deakin University]] awarded him an [[honorary degree|honorary]] [[Master of Science]] degree.<ref>Pescott, Trevor. (1995). ''The You Yangs Range''. Yaugher Print: Geelong. {{ISBN|0-646-23507-9}}</ref>
In 1983 Pescott was awarded the [[Australian Natural History Medallion]].<ref>Hewish, Marilyn. (2005). Trevor Pescott. In: ''Geelong Bird Report 2004'': 69-70. Geelong Field Naturalists Club</ref>
==Bibliography== As well as numerous articles in magazines and journals, books authored and edited by Pescott include: * 1976 - ''By Field and Lane''. Neptune Press: Geelong. * 1978 - ''Natural Victoria''. Rigby: Australia. * 1983 - ''Birds of Geelong''. Neptune Press: Geelong. * 1987 - ''From Buckleys to the Break. A history and natural history of the Barwon River through Geelong''. Geelong Field Naturalists Club: Geelong. (Editor, with Valda Dedman and Gordon McCarthy). * 1995 - ''The You Yangs Range''. Yaugher Print: Geelong. * 1996 - ''Geelong’s Birdlife in Retrospect. A selection of Geelong Advertiser articles by P.J.Wood. 1945-1958''. Yaugher Print: Geelong. (Commentary on historical articles by P.J. Wood). * 1998 - ''The Otway Ranges''. Yaugher Print: Geelong.
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.comment: /* Coal mines */ added Karadon
revision.text:
The '''Zonguldak basin''' of North Western Turkey has been mined for [[coal]] since the late 1800s. The [[sedimentary basin|basin]] takes its name after [[Zonguldak, Turkey]], and is approximately 41° N. The Zonguldak basin is the only basin in Turkey with minable coal deposits. Geographically, the Zonguldak is roughly elliptical in shape with its long axis oriented roughly SW – NE, and is adjacent to the [[Black Sea]]. Three main regions have been recognized in the Zonguldak basin. These are the Armutcuk, the Zonguldak, and the Amasra from west to east respectively.<ref name="SinayuçandGümrah2009">Sinayuç, C., and Gümrah, F. (2009) Modeling of ECBM recovery from Amasra coalbed in Zonguldak Basin, Turkey, International Journal of Coal Geology, 77, 162-174</ref>
==Depositional history==
The Zongdulak basin has undergone two major periods of deposition. The first period of deposition began in the [[Paleozoic]] and the second began in the [[Cretaceous]]. Isolated areas of deposition in the basin occurred during the Late [[Permian]] through the [[Triassic]] and the Latest [[Jurassic]].
===Paleozoic deposition===
The Zonguldak basin first experienced deposition in the [[Ordovician]].<ref name="YalçinandYilmaz2010">Yalçin, M.N. and Yilmaz, I. (2010). Devonian in Turkey – A review. Geologica Carpathica, 61 (3), 235-253</ref> Deposition begins with the lower Ordovician Soḡuksu Formation. The Soḡuksu Fm. ranges from 700 m – 1100 m thick. At its base it consists of green shale and sandstone and coarsens upwards to arkosic conglomerates. The lower Ordovician Aydos Formation conformably overlies the Soḡuksu. It is a conglomerate of quartzitic sandstone and ranges in thickness from 50–200 m. The Findikli Formation was deposited during the upper Ordovician, [[Silurian]], and lower most Devonian in the Zonguldak basin. It ranges from 300 – 450 m thick. Its [[facies]] are indicative of a mixed siliclastic – carbonate shelf environment that is shallowing through time.
The red crossbedded sandstones of the Ferizli Formation overlie the marly deposits of the Fendikli Formation. The oolitic sandstones contain iron and are an iron ore.<ref name="YalçinandYilmaz2010" /> The formation, like the Findikli Fm., shows a shift toward shallower depositional environments and a shift to higher energy areas of deposition. The younger sediments of the Ferizli Fm. become progressively more enriched in [[calcium carbonate]] and eventually give way to the Yilanli Formation.<ref name="YalçinandYilmaz2010" />
The Yilanli Formation is [[Visean]] in age and is the beginning of the coal related sequences in the Zonguldak basin.<ref name="Görüretal1997">Görür, N., Monod, O., Okay, A.I., Sengör, A.M.C., Tüysüz. O., Yiğitbaş, E., Sakinç M., and Akkök, R. (1997) Paleogeographic and tectonic position of the Carboniferous rocks of the western Pontides (Turkey) in the frame of the Variscan belt. Bull. Soc. Géol. France, 168 (2), 195-205</ref><ref name="Hoşgörmez2007">Hoşgörmez, H. (2007). Origin and secondary alteration of coal bed and adjacent rock gasses in the Zonguldak Basin, western Black Sea, Turkey. Geochemical Journal, 41, 201-211</ref> The Yilanli is a dolomitic [[limestone]] unit with calcareous black and gray shales. It was deposited in a shallow marine passive margin setting. It is conformably overlain by the Alacaagzi Formation, and has accumulated over 1000 m of sediment.<ref name="YalçinandYilmaz2010" /> The Alacaagzi Formation contains economic deposits of coal. It is comprised predominantly of crossbedded black [[shale]]s and silts in the lower sections of the unit and progressively becomes composed of sands, shale bearing coals, and conglomerates towards the top of the formation.<ref name="Görüretal1997" /><ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /> Facies analysis in the Alacaagzi Formation is suggestive of a coastal environments including: lacustrine, fluviatial, and fan deposits.<ref name="Görüretal1997" />
Conformably overlaying the Alacaagzi Formation is the Kozlu Formation. The Kozlu contains 19 coal seams totaling 30 – 32 m.<ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /> The Kozlu is composed of successional conglomerate, sand, silt, mud, and coal deposits. The Karadon Formation conformably overlies the Kozlu. The Karadon formation is lithologically similar to the Kozlu Fm. but contains less coal seams. An angular unconformity spans the top of the Karadon formation and ranges from 46.5 [[wikt:Ma|Ma]] – 194 Ma in duration.<ref name="YalçinandYilmaz2010" /><ref name="Yalçinetal1994">Yalçin, M.N., Schenk, H.J., and Schaefer, R.G. (1994). Modeling of gas generation in coals of the Zonguldak basin (northwestern Turkey). International Journal of Coal Geology, 25, 195-212</ref>
===Localized deposition===
Deposition resumes in the western portion of the Zonguldak basin with the deposition of the Çakraz Formation. The Çakraz spans the upper Permian through the Lower Jurassic. Unconformably overlying the Çakraz Fm. is the Inalti Formation. The Inalti was deposited during the upper Jurassic and is truncated by an [[unconformity]].<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /> The carbonates of the Inalti are representative of a shallow passive margin setting.<ref name="Channeletal1996">Channel, J.E.T., Tüysüz, O., Bektas, O., and Sengör, A.M.C. (1996). Jurassic-Cretaceous paleomagnetism and paleography of the Pontides (Turkey). Turkey, 15 (1), 201-212</ref>
===Cretaceous deposition===
During the late Cretaceous, the Zonguldak basin was roughly 25° N,<ref name="Channeletal1996" /> and was experiencing subsidence due to the formation of a back arc, the Black Sea. As a result, the Zonguldak experienced deposition from the early Cretaceous through the [[Eocene]]. Different authors present differing stratigraphic columns of the Zonguldak basin and this analysis will preferentially report more current research. The lithologies deposited during this period of deposition include: limestones, mudstones, siltstones, and [[dolomite]]s.<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /><ref name="Channeletal1996" /> The Albian, 105-100 Ma, Zonguldak Formation is predominantly limestone with areas of dolomitization.<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /><ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002">Hoşgörmez, H., Yalçin, M.N., Cramer, B., Gerling, P., Faber, E., Schaefer, R.G., and Mann, U. (2002). Isotopic and molecular composition of coal-bed gas in the Amasra region (Zonguldak basin—western Black Sea). Organic Geochemistry,33, 1429-1439</ref> It is conformably overlain by the Albian, 105-112 Ma, Kilimli Formation. The Kilimli is composed of sandstone and carbonaceous sandstone.
The Kilimli is unconformably overlain by the sandy limestone of the Cemaller Formation.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" /> The unconformity lasts at least 6.5 Ma and the Zonguldak basin experiences continuous deposition from the Turonian – Campanian. The Cemaller Fm. is overlain by the siltstone and limestone of the Baþköy formation. The Dinlence Formation overlies the Cemaller and consists of [[andesites]] and andesitic tuffites. It is possible that the Dinlence is the Yemislicay Formation since it too contains andesites and andesitic tuffites.<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /><ref name="Channeletal1996" /> The Dinlence is overlain by the marls, and limestones of the Alapý Formation.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" />
==Tectonic history==
===Paleozoic===
During the middle Paleozoic the Zonguldak basin was part of the south facing passive margin of the [[Laurasia]]n plate.<ref name="Görüretal1997" /><ref name="GoncuogluandKozlu2000">Goncuoglu, M.C. and Kozlu, H. (2000). Early Paleozoic evolution of the NW Gondwanaland: Data from southern Turkey and surrounding regions. Gondwana Research, 3, 315-324</ref> During the Carboniferous the temperature of the sediment water interface was near 25 °C and heat flow into the Zonguldak basin was about 1.3 heat flow units (HFU).<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /> Backstripping analysis of the Alacaagzi Fm, the lowest coal-bearing formation, reaches a maximum temperature and depth of 100 °C and 2.4 km respectively in the Zonguldak area during the Carboniferous. Similarly, the base of Kozlu Fm reaches maximum temperatures of 85, 85, and 100 °C in the Armutcuk, the Zonguldak, and the Amasra regions respectively.<ref name="Yalçinetal2002">Yalçin M.N., İnan, S., Gülbin, G., Mann, U., and Schaefer, R.G (2002). Carboniferous coals of the Zonguldak basin (northwest Turkey): Implications for coalbed methane potential. American Association of Petroleum Geologists bulletin, 86 (7), 1305-1328</ref>
The Zonguldak basin was tectonically active during the late Paleozoic and this strongly influenced its structural and burial history due to the [[Hercynian]] [[orogeny]]. The Hercynian orogeny was the result of a continent-continent collision between Laurasia and [[Gondwana]]. This collision created many E-NE/ W-SW striking faults, folds, and tilted the Paleozoic sediments.<ref name="Görüretal1997" /><ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /> This uplift of the basin, near the end of the [[Westphalian (stage)|Westphalian]], halted deposition and created the angular unconformity at the top of the Karadon Fm.<ref name="YalçinandYilmaz2010" /><ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /><ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /> Heat flow remained constant in the Zonguldak basin during the Hercynian Orogeny,<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /> while the uplift caused a decrease in the temperatures the sediments experienced. For example, at the end of the Permian the top of the Alacaagzi is roughly 70 °C and 1.6 km below the sediment surface in the Zonguldak area.
===Mesozoic===
During the Cretaceous the Zonguldak basin experienced general [[subsidence]], [[rift]]ing, and [[fault (geology)|fault]]ing.<ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /> This led to another period of deposition in the region and faulted the coal seams. This faulting provided a pathway for meteoric water to enter the coal seams.
During the [[Aptian]], the Intrapontide Ocean, the ocean separating the Western Pontides tectonic region of Turkey form the Sakarya Continent, underwent subduction.<ref name="Channeletal1996" /> This led to the formation of a back arc basin, the Black Sea. The start of this subduction is responsible for the unconformity between the Kilimi and Cemaller Fms and marks the beginning of the [[Alpide]] orogeny in the region.<ref name="Channeletal1996" /> The andesitic volcaniclastic sediments of the Yemislicay support the subduction of oceanic crust in the region during this time. The Zonguldak basin was able to sustain deposition after the start of the Alpide orogeny due to rifting in the Black Sea basin. The rifting in the Black Sea also increased heat flow into the Zonguldak basin during the Cretaceous. Heat flows were as high as 1.5-1.75 HFU, and the temperature of the sediment water interface was about 25 °C.<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /><ref name="Yalçinetal2002" />
===Cenozoic===
The Intra-Pontide Ocean stopped subducting with the collision between the Western Pontides terrain and the Eastern Pontides terrain. The Aplide orogeny stopped deposition and uplifted the Zonguldak basin during the Eocene epoch beginning at 42 Ma.<ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /><ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /> The coal bearing formations experienced the highest temperatures at the onset of the Alpide orogeny. For example, the base of the Kozlu Fm experienced temperatures of 125, 175, and 140 °C in the Armutcuk, the Zonguldak, and the Amasra regions respectively.<ref name="Yalçinetal2002" />
The Alpide tectonic provinces in [[Anatolia]], from North to South, are the: Pontides, Anatolides, Tarides, and Border Folds. These provinces have rough East-West strike. The Zonguldak basin is currently being uplifted by the Alpide orogeny.<ref name="Yalçinetal2002" /> Progressively older sediments outcrop toward the north of the basin.
==Source rock==
===Coals===
The coals of the Alacaagzi Fm, Kozlu Fm, and Karadon Fm are of bituminous rank.<ref name="Yürümetal2001">Yürüm, Y., Bozkurt, D., and Yalçin, M.N. (2001). Change of the structure of coals from the Kozlu K20 G borehole of Zonguldak Basin with Burial Depth: 1. chemical structure. Energy Sources, 23, 511-520</ref> The Alacaagzi, Kozlu, and Karadon Fms contain greater than: 70% total organic carbon (TOC), 81% TOC, and 81% TOC respectively.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" />
===Structure===
The coals of the Zonguldak basin follow the mean evolution of type III [[kerogen]]s.<ref name="Yürümetal2001" /> The coals of the Zonguldak basin show [[vitrinite]] reflectances (Ro) of 0.45 – 1.70%.<ref name="Yalçinetal2002" /> Hoşgörmez et al., (2002) determined that the coals of the Kozlu Fm exhibit Ro of 1.0 – 1.2% which gives them a coal rank of high volatile A bituminous.<ref name="Strąpoćetal2011">Strąpoć, D., Mastalerz, M., Dawson, K., Macalady, J., Callaghan, A.V., Wawrik, B., Turich, C. and Ashby, M. (2011). Biogeochemistry of microbial coal-bed methane. Annual Review of Earth and Planetary Sciences, 39, 617-656</ref> Additionally, coalification increased with depth, and the coals became more aromatic with depth.<ref name="Karayigitetal1998">Karayigit, A.I., Gayer, R.A., and Demirel, I.H. (1998). Coal rank and petrography of Upper Carboniferous coal seams (Amasra, Turkey). International Journal of Coal Geology, 38, 277-294</ref> The calorification of the coals also increased with depth.
===Methane===
The two broad scale pathways of [[methane]] production, thermogenic and biogenic generation, account for the majority of methane generation in coals.<ref name="Strąpoćetal2011" /> Thermogenic production of methane in coals begins at temperatures around 80 °C and peaks around 0.7 – 1.6% of vitrinite reflectance.<ref name="Strąpoćetal2011" /> Biogenic generation of methane takes place through two chemically distinguishable pathways. These pathways are [[carbon dioxide]] [[redox|reduction]]; and [[acetate]] [[Fermentation (biochemistry)|fermentation]] and methanol/methyl utilization.<ref name="Strąpoćetal2011" /> Typically biogenic production takes place early in the maturation of a coal bed, since the temperatures observed during the coalification process are high enough for sterilization. A coal bed may produce methane later in its history if it is uplifted and fractured. The uplifting of the beds cools them enough for colonization by microbes and fractures and faults provide inoculation pathways by the infiltration of surface water.<ref name="Strąpoćetal2011" />
The coals of the Zonguldak basin were subjected to a complex depositional and tectonic history, and this influenced the basins methane generation. The Alacaagzi Fm did not pass the 80 °C isotherm until it had been buried for 25 Ma.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" /> The Kozlu Fm experienced two different conditions during its first 260 Ma. The bottom of the Kozlu was mostly below the 80 °C isotherm while the top of the formation was above it. With deposition in the Cretaceous, the Kozlu Fm was buried beneath the 80 °C Isotherm. The Alacaagzi, Kozlu were uplifted past the 80 °C around 5 Ma. At this point the rocks had been fractured and meteoric water could inoculate the system with methanogenic microbes.
Isotopic data from wells in the Zonguldak basin suggest that the methane is primarily thermogenic in nature. There may have been some initial microbial methane generation in the coal beds or generation after the basin had been uplifted and meteoric water could enter the beds. Reinoculation is supported by the evidence of isotopically lighter gas occurring near cleats in the coal beds.<ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" />
===Shales===
The organic rich shales of the Yilani contain up to 7.9% TOC, and the shales and siltstones of the coalbearing formations can contain 2 – 26% TOC.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" /> The organic matter is found as type II kerogen. While the Yilani entered the gas window, isotopic data suggest that most of the gas in the basin was derived from the Kozlu coal deposits and the associated organic rich shales.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" />
===Summary of source rock===
The predominant source rock in the Zonguldak basin is coal. The most prolific source rock is the Kozlu Fm containing the greatest volume of coal and the greatest amount of methane. This is in corroboration with the Ro values that suggest thermogenic production of methane in the Zonguldak basin would have been high. Methane generated by shale may be contributing a small amount to the total amount of methane found in the basin but the majority is coal derived. Coal derived methane appears to be mostly thermogenic in origin with some biogenic production.<ref name="Hoşgörmez2007" /><ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" />
==Reservoir==
===Coal===
Coal is the primary reservoir lithology in the Zonguldak basin. Coal, since it is a solid hydrocarbon, cannot migrate. Coal is also an important reservoir lithology in the basin for methane. Methane in coal beds is primarily found in a sorbed state, while a very small fraction is found as a free gas.<ref name="SinayuçandGümrah2009" /> The gas is in the micro-porous structure of the coal at near liquid densities.<ref name="Strąpoćetal2011" /> Hoşgörmez et al. (2002) estimated that the coals of the Zongulak basin contain up to 12 cm<sup>3</sup> g<sup>−1</sup> of methane. Additionally, 90% of the methane in the Karadon Fm is adsorbed to the coal while 10% of it is found as free gas.<ref name="SinayuçandGümrah2009" /> The total volume of coal bed methane in the Karadon Fm in the Amasra region has been estimated to be between 862.5-2600 [[million cubic metre]]s.
===Other units===
The dolomites of the Yilani Fm are characterized as potential reservoir units.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" /> The sandstone units in the Alacaagzi, Kozlu, and Karadon Fms are also potential reservoirs.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" /> Another formation with good reservoir qualities is the Yemislicay or Dinlence Fm.<ref name="Yalçinetal1994" /><ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" /> The base of the Yemislicay is characterized by a red [[pelagic]] limestone interlain with volcaniclastic sediments.<ref name="Channeletal1996" />
==Seals==
Due to the microporous nature of coal, coal is a significant seal in the Zonguldak basin. Outside of the coal bearing formations, the only other formation that can serve as a seal is the Kilimli Formation.<ref name="Hoşgörmezetal2002" />
==Coal mines== Coal mines include [[Armutçuk coal mine]] and [[Karadon coal mine]]

[[File:Sapsaphas Madaba.jpg|thumb|250px|Part of the [[Madaba Map]] showing Ænon]] '''Ænon''', more commonly written '''Aenon''', is the site mentioned by the [[Gospel of John]] as the place where [[John the Baptist|John]] was [[baptism|baptising]] after his encounter with [[Jesus]].<ref name=BigPic >Nichols, Lorna Daniels (2009). ''Big Picture of the Bible: New Testament''. {{ISBN|1-57921-928-4}}. page 12.</ref><ref name=Sloyan11 >Sloyan, Gerard Stephen (1987). ''John''. {{ISBN|0-8042-3125-7}}. page 11.</ref>
"Ænon" is the Greek rendition of the Semitic term for "spring" or "natural fountain", like the Hebrew and Arabic ''{{'}}ayn''. In the water-poor Middle East, places owning a spring tend to be named after that water source, so that toponyms consisting of or containing the [[Construct state]] word "ein-" are common. The particular site mentioned in the Gospel of John is therefore closer identified as "Aenon near Salim". {{Bibleref2|John 3:23}} is the only place in the [[Bible]] where the name Aenon is found.<ref name="cb aenon">John 3:23 is marked with a dagger symbol, used to symbolize the set of all biblical citations of a given word, in Cheyne and Black (1899), ''Encyclopaedia Biblica'', entry for "Aenon." [https://archive.org/details/encyclopaediabib01cheyuoft]</ref>
The name Aenon is commonly used amongst [[Baptist]] organizations and churches.{{Citation needed|date=January 2017}}
==Identification attempts==
===Based on the Gospel text=== Both names, "Aenon" and "Salim", are not unique, and the Gospel text offers only two additional hints about where Aenon might be located: the most direct information is that "there was plenty of water there" ({{Bibleref2|John 3:22}}), and the second is that it was west of the River Jordan because at Aenon John's disciples talk of the site where John first encountered Jesus as being "on the other side of the Jordan" ({{Bibleref2|John 3:26}}) which is taken to mean east of the river. We also know from {{Bibleref2|John 3:28}} that that first encounter happened at "Bethany on the other side of the Jordan".<ref name="BibleHub">{{cite web |url= http://biblehub.com/topical/a/aenon.htm |title= Aenon |work= BibleHub.com |accessdate= 20 March 2015 }}</ref>
One possible location is near the upper source of the [[Wadi al-Far'a (river)|Wadi Fa'rah]], an open valley extending from [[Mount Ebal]] to the [[Jordan River]] which is full of springs. There is a place called 'Ainun four miles north of the springs (see [[Easton's Bible Dictionary]]).<ref name="BibleHub"/>
Another possible location, which is supported by [[Eusebius]]' description in his ''[[Eusebius#Onomasticon|Onomasticon]]'' (written before AD 324), is at "a village in the (Jordan) valley, at the eighth milestone from Scythopolis ([[Beit She'an]]), ... called Salumias."<ref name="OFM">{{cite web |title= Aenon near Salem which is also Saloumias - (Kh. Khisas al-Dayr) |author1= Michele Piccirillo |author2= Eugenio Alliata |author3= Stefano de Luca |work= The Madaba Map: a virtual travel through the Holy Places |publisher= Studium Biblicum Franciscanum - Jerusalem |date= 2000 |url= http://www.christusrex.org/www1/ofm/mad/sources/sources006.html |accessdate= 25 January 2016}}</ref> This view was already supported by the 19th-century [[Smith's Bible Dictionary]] and the 1915 [[International Standard Bible Encyclopedia]]<ref name="BibleHub"/> and is still favoured by some.<ref name="GibsonCave">{{cite book |title= The Cave of John the Baptist: The Stunning Archaeological Discovery that has Redefined Christian History |author= Shimon Gibson |year= 2004 |location= New York |publisher= Doubleday |page= |isbn= 9780385503471 |quote= About twelve kilometres (or eight miles according to Eusebius) to the south of Beth Shean (Scythopolis), there is a region which would fit Aenon perfectly. This location has numerous springs: I have counted thirteen of them in a small area four by four kilometres and, interestingly, [[Ambrose]] in his writings (II, 1432) claimed that there were twelve springs at 'Ennon'. On the north side of this area is Tell Shalem, which undoubtedly must be Salim/Salumnias (map ref. 2098-1998), and so the place where John baptised at Aenon may have been at any of the springs in the vicinity of Tell Shalem. |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=nCdvvTsvuVAC&pg=PT245 |accessdate=25 January 2016 }}</ref><ref name="ICCS">{{cite book |title= A Critical and Exegetical Commentary on the Gospel According to St. John |series= International Critical Commentary Series |author= John Henry Bernard |year= 2000 |location= |publisher= Bloomsbury T&T Clark |page= 128 |isbn= 9780567050243 |quote= |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=VxB4GqeXjSoC&pg=PA128 |accessdate= 25 January 2016 }}</ref>
===Based on the Madaba Map=== The 6th-century [[Madaba Map]] shows the location of Ænon right across the Jordan from [[Bethabara]], near [[Jericho]]. Bethabara is in some, but not all, versions of the Gospel of John the place where John was baptising during his encounter with Jesus.<ref>{{bibleverse-nb||John|1:28|KJV}}</ref> The map and archaeological findings at the site indicate that at least during part of the Byzantine period, this was the site venerated as Aenon. The two relevant map inscriptions read
* Αίνών ένθα νύν ό Σαπσαφάς: "Ænon, where now is Sapsaphas" * Βέθαβαρά το τού άγίου Ιωάννου τού βαπτίσματος: "Bethabara, the place of baptism of St. John"
With the Dead Sea shown on the right side of the map giving context, Bethabara is on the west of the Jordan, while Ænon is on the east.
